story:

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Meryl Bird
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

After a short but difficult battle with cancer, my mum, Meryl, peacefully passed away on 30 November 2020, aged 53. 

In this (covid) year, above all other years, the NHS and Macmillan cancer support have had to do more, work harder and overcome challenges never faced before. Through every moment of my mums treatment and illness, Macmillan were there for her, at times when I couldn't be. I cannot thank them enough for the care and support they gave my mother, and me, through her illness. 

They deserve more than any of us could ever give, but I hope a small collection can make a small difference.

The one good thing to come out of 2020 has been all the stories of kindness, of helping others and people doing their bit. And that's something to celebrate, and to carry on. 

So for my small part I am trying to do a good deed every day until Dec 25th - an advent calendar of kindness. The deeds don't have to be grand and those in receipt don't have to be 'needy' but hopefully every deed will put a smile on someone's face. Here is the calendar I will try to complete:

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation because without their work I wouldn’t be here today. I have complex heart defects and three years ago I was being assessed for a heart/lung transplant and I slowly got more poorly. In December 19 I was given a lifeline and had a heart valve put in my heart, they didn’t think it’d help me with breathlessness and my oxygen saturation’s etc but they were confident it’d help me ‘inside’ however, my whole life changed overnight, my breathlessness almost disappeared, my oxygen sats increased and my overall health completely changed. During lockdown and so far I’ve walked 78k so I’d have to do about half that in a month! I’ve chosen February as it is National Heart Month with the 7-14th being National Congenital Heart Disease week, so this is when I’m wanting to do the bulk of my walk. 26.2 miles in 28 days may be a doddle to some, but I still experience high levels of fatigue so it is a challenge for me  

I have lost far too many friends to this disease already at such young ages and it shouldn’t be happening and just £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thank you xxx

story:
2020 has been a difficult year for many people and something which has added to this experience for some, has been job loss, feelings of insecurity in exploring other options or going forward for a promotion.  I'm currently on a period of maternity leave and as a qualified and experienced career and coaching professional, wanted to give something back during this time on behalf of my daughter and I.  The idea is simple:

If you'd like help with exploring your options and job search, or improving your CV or applications, or practising your interview technique and receiving feedback etc. then just get in touch and we'll arrange some time to make this happen.  Email careerkarma20@gmail.com with your request.

All interactions are confidential.  Over 18s only.  If you're a Northumbria University student or graduate then please visit the Graduate Futures webpage for support directly from the University: https://www.northumbria.ac.uk/study-at-northumbria/planning-your-career/careers-and-employment/ 

After you've received the help, you make a donation (however much you can afford to give) to Guide Dogs.  This is one of many charities which has been hit badly by the pandemic but one which undertakes life changing work and one for which there is still a big demand from service users.  I've set a target of £2500 to name a puppy and will continue to support others free of charge until I've reached this target.

Of course if you're already in a dream role, like this idea and would like to contribute then please feel free to do so.

The photo linked to this page is of my beautiful labrador, Woody, who we sadly lost this year.

Thank you all for reading.

Ashleigh

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My daughter was Diagnosed with third degree complete heart block at 18 months old... Whist she appeared fine her heart did not act as it should.. When a child walks into a room singing and dancing their hearts are racing, summers condition meant her heart was super slow even when racing around having fun and extremely low during periods of rest. The concern of her condition was it would cause fainting and her her to black out since her heart was not working as most people's should. 

I was advised to let her continue through her early years as normal but to keep an eye out of any signs of dizziness, fainting and blackouts, this left me anxious to leave her, she eventually began nursery however I was concerned to go afar from my hometown incase she needed me... This is how loades of cakes blossomed, a way of working, showing her I could support her and still be there if she needed me. 

Eventually at the age of 7 she began showing signs she needed some help with her condition and so she had her 1st pacemaker fitted, she's now 11 and is on her 2nd pacemaker.. Its fair to say she's amazing!! Her pacemaker kicks in when her heart beats below 40bpm. And has aleviated all of the concerning side effects she began showing. 

What was also amazing for me was the Care we got from Great Ormond Street, from the doctor who hugged me in the corridor after hearing her diagnosis, I was a young single mum, petrified and the hug is one I will never forget, to the one who blew her giant bubbles on the bed whilst I listened to how this would affect her future life. To the amazingly skilled Surgeons who filled us with reassurance when she was going into her first operation, the nurses who monitored her every hour after her operation, the volunteers who have helped us find wards, the volunteers working at the shop, absolutely every one... Though summers condition meant she can lead a fairly normal life, so many other children their can't. 


I wanted to make something to raise some money for the hospital, its a difficult time for us all so just a share is appreciated but if you can make a donation every donation will be entered into a raffle to win this Gingerbread House. I will announce the winner Saturday 19th December, just in time for Christmas, winner must collect from PE26 1ER. 

Anyway its Christmas, and I always reflect on what I'm most grateful for and really wanted to raise a little money for this amazing Hospital and in doing so giving you all a chance to win something pretty in return.

At times over the last seven years GOSH has been many things to us. A life saver, a sanctuary, a place of safety, somewhere to turn when things get tough, a place full of hope but above all a reassuring constant in the background.

We have spent more than our fair share here. Despite that, and 8 operations to date - it remains a place full of people who feel like friends - the most amazing of staff.

Whilst no amount of money would ever be enough to say thank you for all they have done for us, as a family and will continue to do...its a start.

We want to give something back.

Not forgetting the pioneering research they do to help the lives of children.

It's quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the Give Now button!

Wish me luck ! Especially if it snows !

story:
As many of you may know Great Ormond Street Hospital is very close to us and our families, during the years of 1981-1982 our sister spent a lot of time at the hospital being treated for a very rare condition and at 3 years of age she sadly passed away. Although they couldn't save our sister the work they done for her and many other children is unbelievable. Therefore, every year we donate this amazing charity, however with 2020 being such a challenging year we have decided to do something special. This January, we are kickstarting 2021 by taking part in Running off Christmas. we will be running 31 miles each throughout the month to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity (GOSH Charity).
After all the festivities and with the cold and wet weather January can bring, your donations to support Great Ormond Street Hospital's life saving work will keep us going when we need it most. It's quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the Give Now button! GOSH's patients, families and staff need your support now more than ever. story:
I am running for Great Ormond Street Hospital because the hospital does amazing work. I have a close friend that was treated at Gosh, who will always be in our hearts. The hospital saved my best friend Tia’s life.

When she was 2 she was diagnosed with Dilated Cardiomyopathy, this is heart failure. The condition is very serious. She became really ill very quickly. Tia had 12 operations on her heart before she was sent to Great Ormond Street. She was taken straight to intensive care. Tia was very very poorly. Her family were told that the only way to save Tia and keep her alive, was to have a heart transplant. Tias parents said it was such a scary time, they just wanted their little girl to be ok, they couldn’t bare the thought of loosing her.
They made the decision to put her on the urgent transplant list straight away.

Tia was put into a coma as she was to weak to breath for herself. The family were just praying for a miracle. Tia was to poorly to wait for a donor on her own so she was fitted with a Berlin heart. This is a machine that attached to Tias heart, it worked Tias heart for her as her heart wasn't working anymore. The operation for this was a big one, it took 14 hours. Tia stayed in intensive care in a drug induced coma for 4 months.
In total she had been in intensive care for 7 months and in a coma for 4. Tia was taken out of the coma just before Christmas. She had to be taught how to walk again as she had lost all her muscle, she had also lost so much weight so she was very weak.

Thankfully in April 2010 after being on the list 5 months Tia had the call to say they had found a donor heart for her. Her Mum and Dad gave her a massive hug and handed her over to the amazing Doctors, Nurses and Surgeons hoping and praying that Tia would pull through this operation. The team worked all through the night for Tia and after 12 long hours she came back to intensive care without her Berlin heart, it had been replaced with a shiny new heart. Her amazing donor family made this happen along with all the hospital staff. I know Tia's family and friends are so grateful. Tia has to take medicine everyday to stop her heart rejecting. I always remind her if we are out, or having a sleepover. I try my best to look after Tia. She still goes to Gosh every couple of months. Sadly this year right in the middle of the Covid pandemic she became unwell, she sadly had rejection. I was scared for her, and so were her family. She had to stay in hospital and have high doses of medicines. Thankfully this worked for her. She is being very closely monitored, but the main thing is she is here with us all.

Without Great Ormond Street my best friend wouldn’t be here. I want to give back whatever I can to show them I am so grateful for what they do. I am a gymnast and during the lockdowns I have been running a lot as my gym has been closed. I enjoy the running as it keeps me fit. I thought this challenge would be a good way to raise money for this amazing charity. Tia's Mum always says she wouldn’t wish their situation on anyone. She does also say that everyone should find comfort in knowing that if your child did become seriously unwell, Great Ormond Street are there for you and they will help you as much as they can. They saved Tias life on many occasions and for that we are truly grateful. I am hoping to raise as much money as possible for Gosh. If you could donate to my page I would be so grateful. No donation is to small, every little helps. Thank you for reading my page, stay safe and have a very merry Christmas.
Love Nicole xx

story:
Having lived by the sea all of my life, I am very appreciative of all the wonders of this incredible resource. As a keen sailor I have huge respect for the sea and even more respect for the brave men and women of the Howth RNLI who have assisted so many of my friends over the years. Despite living as close to the sea as it is possible without being in it, I have only recently started sea swimming, a Lockdown activity I took up in March of this year. Our daily (Socially Distanced) swims have kept us healthy in mind and body throughout this difficult year and have made me even more aware of the importance of the Lifeboat to us all. Due to the restrictions imposed on us all by the virus many fund raising events have been curtailed. To this end, would you be willing to support me in my Christmas Day swim and make a small contribution to Howth RNLI. My (no wet suit) swim will last approx. 15 minutes. Scorie

Thats because half of all UK species are in decline were losing our precious red squirrels, hedgehogs and birds at an alarming rate. By taking part in The Big Winter Wander, you and your friends and family can reconnect with our country's beautiful wildlife and help protect it. The funds you raise will help us campaign to protect wildlife here, and around the world. Nature has been there to offer us comfort during difficult times, and now its our time to give back.

story:
I'm 40! But I don't need your congratulations or sympathy. I want your money. Please use my entry into middle/old age as an excuse to donate to this fantastically worthy cause.

More and more countries are retreating from their global obligations, focusing on problems closer to home. But the need hasn't gone away. Médecins Sans Frontières is an international organisation bringing medical help to those most in need around the world. COVID-19 has made their work more important, and more difficult. So there's never been a better time to donate to them.

Please give generously!
